Five Things to Save a Life
FIRST - Place the victim on his or her back. Make sure he or she is lying as flat as possible.
SECOND - Push hard, push fast in the middle of the chest at least 2 inches (5 centimeters) deep and at least 100 compressions per minute.

THIRD - Tilt the head back and lift the chin up.
 - Pinch the nose shut then make a complete seal over the person’s mouth.
 - Blow in for about 1 second to make the chest clearly rise.
 - Give rescue breaths, one after the other.

Note: If chest does not rise with rescue breaths, retilt the head and give another rescue breath.

FOURTH - Continue cycles of CPR. Do not stop CPR except in one of these situations:
 - You find an obvious sign of life, such as breathing.
 - An AED is ready to use.
 - Another trained responder or EMS personnel take over.
 - You are too exhausted to continue.
 - The scene becomes unsafe.
FIRST - Give 5 back blows. Bend the person forward at the waist and give 5 back blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of one hand.

SECOND - Give 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
 - Place a fist with the thumb side against the middle of the person’s abdomen, just above the navel.
 - Cover your fist with your other hand.
 - Give 5 quick, upward abdominal thrusts.

THIRD - Continue sets of 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until the:
 - Object is forced out.
 - Person can cough forcefully or breathe.
 - Person becomes unconscious.
FIRST - Cover the wound with a sterile dressing.
SECOND - Apply direct pressure until bleeding stops.
THIRD - Cover the dressing with bandage. Check for circulation beyond the injury (check for feeling, warmth and color).
FIRST - Remove from source of burn.
SECOND - Cool the burn with cold running water at least until pain is relieved.
THIRD - Cover loosely with sterile dressing and care for shock.
FIRST - Take the person out of water, look to see if the person’s chest is moving and check the person’s pulse for 10 seconds.
SECOND - If the person can’t breath start CPR (Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation), see CPR section for instructions.
